name: Suicide Death Rates US
title: Suicide Death Rates US

api_list.name: /records
api_list.description: The 'records' endpoint is the key component of the 'SuicideDeathRatesUS' API, providing valuable information to users seeking data about suicide death rates in the United States. This endpoint serves as the gateway to accessing a wealth of insights in the form of an array of objects. Each object represents a specific row of data associated with the query parameters defined by the user.By utilizing the 'records' endpoint, individuals can gain a comprehensive understanding of suicide death rates based on their specific interests or requirements. The array of objects returned offers a structured and organized representation of the available data, ensuring users can easily navigate and interpret the information they seek.Whether researchers investigating trends, journalists crafting informative articles, or concerned citizens aiming to raise awareness, this endpoint empowers users to extract relevant insights on suicide death rates in the United States. With the 'records' endpoint, users can delve into comprehensive and valuable data that facilitates a deeper understanding of such a critical topic.

api_list.name: /year
api_list.description: The 'year' endpoint from the 'SuicideDeathRatesUS' API provides an array of strings that represent the possible values for the field 'year'. This endpoint allows users to access a comprehensive list of years for which suicide death rates data is available. It enables users to explore and retrieve specific data related to different years, such as suicide mortality rates, demographics, and trends. The values returned by this endpoint are typically in the format of four-digit numbers, representing individual years. By using this endpoint, users can gain insights into how suicide rates have fluctuated over time, analyze patterns, and identify any significant changes or occurrences. It serves as a useful resource for researchers, policymakers, and individuals interested in understanding the temporal aspects of suicide death rates in the United States.

api_list.name: /unit
api_list.description: The 'unit' endpoint from the 'SuicideDeathRatesUS' API provides a list of different measurements used to quantify suicide death rates in the United States. These measurements indicate the number of deaths per 100,000 residents and allow for comparisons across different populations and time periods.The endpoint returns an array of strings representing various units of measurement. These units include rates adjusted for age and population (age-adjusted deaths per 100,000 resident population), overall crude death rates (crude deaths per 100,000 resident population), and other variations of deaths per 100,000 resident population.By accessing this endpoint, users can retrieve a comprehensive list of available measurement units related to suicide death rates. This information can be particularly useful for researchers, policymakers, and health professionals seeking to analyze and compare suicide statistics within the United States.

api_list.name: /dataListIndex
api_list.description: The 'dataListIndex' endpoint in the 'SuicideDeathRatesUS' API provides an array of strings representing possible values for a particular field called 'dataListIndex'. This field is crucial for obtaining specific information from the API related to suicide death rates in the United States. Each string value within the array corresponds to a unique identifier or code that categorizes different aspects of suicide data, such as age groups, gender, geographic regions, or years. By utilizing these values, users can tailor their API requests to retrieve data based on their specific requirements. The 'dataListIndex' endpoint essentially serves as a reference to explore and discover the available categories and subcategories of information related to suicide death rates in the United States.

api_list.name: /stubLabel
api_list.description: The 'stubLabel' endpoint in the 'SuicideDeathRatesUS' API provides a useful array of strings representing various categories or labels related to suicide death rates in the United States. These labels help to categorize and differentiate different aspects of the data. For example, one such label could be 'Female: 15-19 years', indicating the specific age group of females between 15 and 19 years old. Another label could be 'Male: Not Hispanic or Latino: Asian or Pacific Islander', representing males who identify as Asian or Pacific Islander and are not of Hispanic or Latino descent. These labels allow users to identify and sort the data based on specific demographic information such as gender, age, and ethnicity, providing a comprehensive view of suicide death rates across various categories. By utilizing the 'stubLabel' endpoint, users can access an extensive list of potential labels to enhance their analysis and understanding of suicide death rates in the United States.

api_list.name: /stubName
api_list.description: The 'stubName' endpoint in the 'SuicideDeathRatesUS' API provides a user-friendly way to retrieve an array of strings representing various options available for the 'stubName' field. This field refers to the specific categories or groupings that can be used to filter and analyze suicide death rate data in the United States.By making a request to this endpoint, users can obtain a list of possible values that can be used to classify and segment the data based on different criteria. These values might include categories such as sex and age, sex and race, Hispanic origin, or a combination of these factors.For example, if someone wants to analyze suicide death rates based on different age groups or explore variations in rates among different racial or ethnic groups, they can refer to this endpoint to retrieve the available 'stubName' options. These options can then be used in further API requests to filter and retrieve the desired data.In essence, the 'stubName' endpoint helps users identify the specific classification options available for analyzing suicide death rates in the US, enabling them to explore the data from different angles and perspectives.

api_list.name: /age
api_list.description: The 'age' endpoint in the 'SuicideDeathRatesUS' API provides a comprehensive array of age groups related to suicide death rates in the United States. This endpoint offers valuable information on the varying age demographics affected by suicide, facilitating a better understanding and analysis of suicide-related data. By querying this endpoint, users gain access to a range of age categories, each representing a distinct stage of life. These categories contribute to a comprehensive overview of suicide rates across different age groups. Understanding age-specific trends is crucial in identifying potential risk factors and implementing targeted intervention strategies.Through this endpoint, users can extract valuable insights such as trends in adolescent suicide rates (e.g., 15-19 years), evaluate the impact of suicide on diverse age brackets (e.g., 'All ages'), and even investigate the vulnerability of older individuals (e.g., 85 years and over). Accessing the 'age' endpoint empowers users to explore and analyze suicide death rates specific to various age cohorts, aiding in the formulation of targeted prevention efforts and informed policymaking.

api_list.name: /estimate
api_list.description: The 'estimate' endpoint from the 'SuicideDeathRatesUS' API returns an array of strings that represent the estimated values for suicide death rates in the United States. These estimates provide insights into the magnitude of suicides in different regions or time periods. Each string value in the array corresponds to a specific estimate, and typically ranges between 0 and 100. These estimates help analysts, researchers, and policymakers understand the prevalence and trends of suicide rates in the country. By examining these values, one can gain valuable information about the impact of suicide on public health and identify areas that require attention and intervention. These estimates can be further used to compare suicide rates between states, demographics, or other relevant factors, aiding in the development of targeted preventive measures and support systems.
